Posts.Content: Aug 5, 2013 05:29PM MikeJohn wrote: Sounds like the neuropathy I have in my feet, as well.  I use Gabapentin for the pain (was on 3000 mgs back in 2012) now I'm down to 900 mg.  Slowly starting to try a small dose of Lyrica. God bless you.
Posts.Title: Sudden neuropathy in feet keepingon MikeJohn

Posts.Content: MikeJohn wrote: Just a question to pose to all of you:  My sons are both teenagers in college, I have bone and liver mets.  I have been totally honest with them, but lately, after my latest diagnosis, I'm considering how much I should tell them.  Could you please give me some input on how much you have told your children?  Thank you. Posts.Title: Children Question MikeJohn invisible

Posts.Content: MikeJohn wrote: I am writing to ask for input.  My wife was diagnosed with breast cancer in 2011, and in 2012 she was diagnosed with chemo-induced peripheral neuropathy.  She went from using a wheelchair in January and February, to a walker in March, to AFO's (braces) from April to December.  The very day that she walked without braces, she was told that she had bone metastasis.  She has had many crying days and a lot of fear.  It has almost seemed to have gotten worse over the past seven months.  I've noticed that she has become scared of eating certain foods.  We have college-age sons, and it has always been a goal of hers to see her grandchildren.    Do any of you have any information or tips that I can share with her that will encourage her, help her to not cry, become less fearful, and to eat because she's losing weight?  She has had fear issues much of her life, and I'm afraid that the fear is decreasing her immunity and slowing her healing.  Thank you for your time in responding. And God bless you all with healing!  Nahum 1:7 Dx 4/26/2011, IBC, Stage IIIB, 7/20 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Chemotherapy 4/29/2011 Taxol (paclitaxel) Surgery 7/6/2011 Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel; Mastectomy: Right Radiation Therapy 8/1/2011 3DCRT: Breast Chemotherapy 9/19/2011 Ixempra (ixabepilone), Xeloda (capecitabine) Hormonal Therapy 12/30/2011 Arimidex (anastrozole) Dx 12/5/2012, IBC, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Dx 1/15/2013, IBC, Stage IV, mets Targeted Therapy 1/28/2013 Afinitor (everolimus) Radiation Therapy 4/1/2013 Bone Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Anxiety and fear MikeJohn KiwiCatMom

Posts.Content: MikeJohn wrote: I have recently been diagnosed with bone mets (Jan. '13) and then liver mets (Aug. '13), and I'm going back to M.D. Anderson Tuesday to discuss treatment options. My oncologist was not the one who told me this latest diagnosis (he was out of the country). The doctor who told me was very negative and treated me as a statistic.  She was very negative about my life expectancy with this condition.  The next day my local oncologist wsa more positive; however, I have had a very difficult time keeping her negative words from ruining each and every day.  She spent very little time with me discussing anything with me but seemed to indicate that the progression to the liver was just devastating.  How do you keep negative comments like this from destroying your hope? How do you keep it from ruining your time with your family?  How do you ever feel normal again? I request your prayers that my MD Anderson oncologist will be more positive and hopeful about a treatment, and for my mind to get some peace from these tormenting thoughts. Any optimistic thoughts or tips that you have would be very much appreciated.  Thank you. Dx 4/26/2011, IBC, Stage IIIB, 7/20 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Chemotherapy 4/29/2011 Taxol (paclitaxel) Surgery 7/6/2011 Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel; Mastectomy: Right Radiation Therapy 8/1/2011 3DCRT: Breast Chemotherapy 9/19/2011 Ixempra (ixabepilone), Xeloda (capecitabine) Hormonal Therapy 12/30/2011 Arimidex (anastrozole) Dx 12/5/2012, IBC, Stage IV, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Dx 1/15/2013, IBC, Stage IV, mets Targeted Therapy 1/28/2013 Afinitor (everolimus) Radiation Therapy 4/1/2013 Bone Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Prayer request MikeJohn sameheart8

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2013 11:38PM MikeJohn wrote: Returned from MDAnderson.  My oncologist quoted me the same dismal statistic of survivor rates for my situation (IBC to bone mets to liver mets).  I was very disappointed that he really didn't encourage me at all.  He basically threatened to take me off of my treatment before he started any treatment, telling me that I had to learn to COPE better the next time I got disappointing news.  I'm even more scared now knowing that not only is he going to fight with me, it sounds like he is giving up.  He suggested either Gemzab or Halaven...whatever my local oncologist wanted to try.  Am I crazy for wanting to get another opinion or to try to find someone who believes in his/her own treatments enough to give me some shread of encouragement.  The disease is wearing me down enough without having doubts about my own oncologist.  I also found out after thinking that I was Triple Positive for 2 1/3 years, that I  was HER2 negative.  What does that mean to me now?
Posts.Title: Prayer request MikeJohn sameheart8

Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2013 07:14PM MikeJohn wrote: Thank you ladies for your info and encouragement.  I just want to see my children graduate college, get married, and see and keep grandchildren one day. How do focus on one day at a time instead of dreams that you once had?  I'm still shell-shocked from this.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with Liver Mets. Can anyone encourage me? MikeJohn scuttlers

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2013 05:00PM MikeJohn wrote: I was just soooo discouraged when the doctor (who was not my regular oncologist) gave the news, didn't really go over the report, and told me that I had about a year to live.  I just want to know, "Do you ladies think I should look at other places for treatment? Or, give my oncologist a chance? Have any of you ever had negative comments from doctors?  I love the comment from CafeLvr about her doctor telling her that she would see her grandchildren graduate.  That's what I'm praying for. My bone mets are still stable. The liver spots just showed up within the last two months.
